text:
Date and Time
Friday, 24 May 2019
5:00 PM - 7:00 PM CEST


Venue
Vienna University of Economics and Business
Welthandelspl. 1, 1020 Vienna


About
It is our pleasure to announce Bettina Grün as our next speaker for this Friday’s Meetup.
Bettina will be giving a talk on “Extending R with Packages”.
After the talk we will go for some drinks in one of the restaurants at the WU Campus.
We are looking forward to seeing you on Friday!


Speaker
Bettina Grün
Bettina is an Associate Professor of Applied Statistics at JKU Linz. She is an active member of the R community and has written our co-authored numerous R packages such as flexmix, topicmodels, bayesmix, arules, exams, movMF and betareg. Moreover, she is an ordinary member of the R Foundation and currently serves as Editor-in-Chief for the Journal of Statistical Software.

title: PyLadies and R-Ladies Vienna: Intro to Python
text:
(This is part of a series of joint events with PyLadies Vienna)


Date and Time
Wednesday, 24 March 2021
6:00 PM - 8:00 PM CET


Venue
Online


About
We are proud to announce the collaboration between PyLadies Vienna and R-Ladies Vienna for a series of events aimed at fostering the collaboration and synergies between our communities.
We invite you to join us for the first event of the series: Workshop on introduction to Python. Whether you are already proficient in R and want to gradually add Python to your portfolio, or want to learn some programming basics in a faster pace in a form of a lecture, this tutorial will serve as a starting point for your journey.
The agenda of the workshop will be:

Intro to Python - syntax, loop, functions
Basic data types and structures
Reading data
Examples and use cases

To be able to follow the course and try things yourselves, we recommend to install Python (add to PATH if on Windows). If you do not have a favorite code editor, we would suggest to install Atom or VSCode else feel free to use what you like.
Can’t wait to meet you and share some love for Python!
Both events are preliminary steps to our final event: Panel Discussion about conjunction of both worlds with PyLadies and R-Ladies on board, which will take place on 27.3.2021.
We also have a facebook group to share ideas or questions.
RSVP via Meetup

title: Managing R projects with Maëlle Salmon
text:
Date and Time
Tuesday, 16 November 2021
12:00 PM - 1:00 PM CET


Venue
Online


About
After a long summer break we are happy to announce the November 2021 Meetup with Maëlle Salmon, who will give us a presentation on best practices to organize an R project and why R projects are important.
Here is Maëlle’s abstract for the talk: “A good R project organization is useful even if you do not have collaborators as demanding as The Little Prince. How to do that? Do you put the project in some sort of box? In this talk I will present tools that are good to know: git, here, renv, targets, orderly … I’ll also report whether making an R package out of everything is always a good idea. After this presentation you will have learnt tips and tricks to apply as you like in your R projects. I hope every one of you will learn at least one new thing!”
We are so happy to have Maëlle contribute to our Meetup! See you soon online!


Speaker
Maëlle Salmon
Maëlle is a part-time research software engineer for rOpenSci (since February 2018) and an active R developer and trainer. She also serves as associate editor for rOpenSci’s Software Peer Review (peer-review system of R packages) and is the main manager of R-Ladies Global Twitter account.

title: Switching between space and time: Spatio-temporal analysis with cubble
text:
Abstract
Weather data have a spatial component given by the station coordinates and a temporal component that provides measurements on precipitation, maximum and minimum temperature. This will be a hand-on session to work with weather station data. We will use the package sf to work on the spatial side to generate some maps and the package tsibble to conduct some exploratory data analysis on the temporal side. One way to communicate space and time information together is through a glyph map where temporal coordinates are transformed into space. We will create the glyph map with the ggplot geom: geom_glyph(). Lastly, we will experiment with a new data structure, cubble, to arrange spatio-temporal data.

title: Joint May Event: RLadies Vienna x Vienna<-R
text:
Date and Time
Wednesday, 24 May 2023
6:00 PM - 8:00 PM CEST


Venue
TU Wien - Seminarraum 107/1 (im ehem. “Goldenen Lamm”)
Wiedner Hauptstraße 7, 1040 Vienna


About
We are happy to announce Bettina Grün and Benjamin Schwendinger as the speakers for our next joint event with the ViennaR meetup group!
Benjamin Schwendinger will talk about the data.table package, which is a widely used, high-performance extension of base R’s data.frame. In this talk, we will cover the latest development steps of the package over the last few years. We will also shed light on how data.table gains its speed and how useRs can ensure that it is used to its full potential.
Bettina Grün will be giving a talk on R Packages, walking us through important guidelines for extending R with packages. This talk will be interesting for R package developers and useRs alike.


Speaker
Bettina Grün, Benjamin Schwendinger

title: PyLadies and R-Ladies Vienna: Panel discussion
text:
(This is part of a series of joint events with PyLadies Vienna)


Date and Time
Saturday, 27 March 2021
4:00 PM - 6:00 PM CET


Venue
Online


About
We invite you to join us for the third event of our joint series with PyLadies: Panel Discussion - R and Python with experts. Whether you are familiar with only R, Python, mastering both of them or just starting your journey now, we think this is the event for you.
During the unique connection of both worlds of R and Python, you shall hear about from our awesome panelists, who will try to answer all your possible questions.
See you soon!

Panelists
Oliwia Lewandowska - Data Scientist at Looping Group, Berlin with a focus on Natural Language Processing & Data Storytelling. She is experienced in R and SQL, and passionate about mastering Python.
Jillian Augustine - Data scientist in the Digital Excellence team at Mondi Group. Through her background in molecular biology as well as having worked in the telecommunications and manufacturing industries, she has experience working on a diverse range of use cases using both R and Python.
Alexandra Avalos Pacheco - Postdoctoral fellow in Statistics at Harvard Medical School in the Harvard-MIT Center for Regulatory Science (CRS) and part of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (DFCI) in the Department of Data Science.
Olivera Janic - Quantitative Credit Risk Analyst at Raiffeisen Bank International (RBI). She has 7 years of experience in Market and Credit Risk Management. Her R journey started at Vienna University of Economics and Business during master studies in Quantitative Finance and continued at RBI where Python came along. Automatization, software engineering and diverse credit risk calculations are part of her daily routine.
Our Panel Discussion will be moderated by Kseniya Khamina, Scientist, PhD in Immunology, with experience in genetics and virology.

title: Natural Language Processing in R
text:
Date and Time
Tuesday, 21 November 2023
6:00 PM - 8:00 PM CET


Venue
TU Wien - Seminarraum 107/1 (im ehem. “Goldenen Lamm”)
Wiedner Hauptstraße 7, 1040 Vienna


About
In our next meetup we will discuss natural language processing (NLP) in R. We will hear two presentations:

Florian Schwendinger: Introduction to NLP in R
Camilla Damian: Detecting Gender Bias in Children’s Books
Flo will first give a general overview of the topic and show relevant R packages (see also the CRAN Task View on the topic of NLP).
This will be followed by an application described by Camilla: Gender stereotypes form early in the child’s development and are carried over throughout adolescence into adulthood, leaving long-lasting effects which may impact activity and career choices, as well as academic performance. Books, in particular, can have considerable influence, as their characters serve to shape role models of femininity and masculinity for young children. Thus, gender under- and misrepresentation in children’s textual literature can contribute to the internalization and reinforcement of stereotypes. To address this issue, we aim to identify and measure relevant dimensions of gender bias in children’s books with the aid of both qualitative and quantitative techniques: systematic literature review across disciplines on the one hand and natural language processing (NLP) methods on the other. By exploiting such an integrated research framework, we believe that it is possible to automate the detection of potentially biased text while enhancing the interpretability and transparency of the results.



Speaker
Florian Schwendinger, Camilla Damian
RSVP via Meetup

title: How groups manage conflict: Sequence Analysis using TraMineR
text:
Abstract
Within and across organisations, groups are formed to tackle situations that require a decision or recommendation to be made, whether the situation is simple or complex, routine or one-off, short or long-term. However, inconsistencies between group members’ definitions of the situation often gives rise to conflict. Within the management and system sciences, various model-driven support approaches have been developed to assist groups in revealing disagreements and managing conflict. In this study, we investigate whether the preference for deliberate and deep information processing, also known as epistemic motivation, affects an important feature of model-driven group decision support. It serves as an aid to surface and manage cognitive conflict within the group. We report on an experimental study that adopts a process-oriented methodology to examine conflict management behaviors and trajectories of groups with different levels of epistemic motivation. Using TraMineR: Sequence Analysis Toolkit, we show how conflict management trajectories are influenced by epistemic motivation of groups. The results indicate that three dimensions of epistemic motivation; discomfort with ambiguity, decisiveness, preference for order and structure are significant co-variates of variance in groups’ conflict management trajectories.

title: Joint Event: Women in Tech Initiatives Meetup @PyDays
text:
Date and Time
Friday, 3 May 2019
4:00 PM - 5:00 PM CEST


Venue
University of Applied Sciences Technikum Wien
Höchstädtpl. 6, 1200 Vienna


About
Technologists create products and services and in doing so affect our everyday lives now and in the future. If these products and services are supposed to serve our society as a whole, we need a lot of diverse and creative perspectives reflecting the richness of our communities. Therefore, we strongly believe that striving to increase diversity among technologists should be a major goal.
On our pursuit for diversity, one of the most encouraging things we can do is to highlight those women who already work on great things within their respective industries, provide them platforms to share their knowledge and inspire by their example.
In Vienna, a range of initiatives promoting gender diversity in STEM (science, technology, engineering & math) exist. To increase visibility as well as to facilitate exchange of ideas and getting-to-know-each-other amongst these initiatives, a session solely dedicated to these groups and projects will take place during PyDays Vienna.
Enlisted Initiatives

Co-Mentoring Programme - Women in Data Science
Feminist Python Meetup for Women* and Non-Binary Folks in Vienna
Feminist Linux Meetup für Frauen*, Non-Binary*, Trans* und Inter* Personen
diebin.at - Verein zur Förderung emanzipatorischer Informations- und Kommunikationstechnologien
R-Ladies Vienna
IEEE Women in Engineering

People of all genders are welcome to attend our event. Find out more about the initiatives.
RSVP via Meetup

title: About us
text:
R-Ladies Vienna is a non-profit organization and a local chapter of R-Ladies Global. We promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide, with a mission to achieve proportionate representation of genders currently underrepresented.
We organize regular events and meetups in-person and/or online to connect with the community. Our priority is to provide a safe and inclusive community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R, and at the same time welcome all identities to participate in our events.
We welcome members of all R proficiency levels, from new aspiring R users to experienced R programmers interested in mentoring, networking and expert upskilling. Our community is designed to develop our members’ R skills and knowledge through social, collaborative learning and sharing. We support the access of minority identities to STEM skills and careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!

title: About us
text:
R-Ladies Vienna is a non-profit organization and a local chapter of R-Ladies Global. We promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide, with a mission to achieve proportionate representation of genders currently underrepresented.
We organize regular events and meetups in-person and/or online to connect with the community. Our priority is to provide a safe and inclusive community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R, and at the same time welcome all identities to participate in our events.
We welcome members of all R proficiency levels, from new aspiring R users to experienced R programmers interested in mentoring, networking and expert upskilling. Our community is designed to develop our members’ R skills and knowledge through social, collaborative learning and sharing. We support the access of minority identities to STEM skills and careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!

title: About us
text:
Participation Guideline
We follow the code of conduct and community guidelines of R-Ladies Global.
The leadership, mentoring & teaching roles within this Community are held exclusively by minority genders, with learning participation opened to all genders. Anyone involved with R-Ladies Vienna is expected to fully respect each other, the mandate of this community, and the goodwill on which R-Ladies is founded.
As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of the R-Ladies communities around the world.

title: About us
text:
Media use
Please note that by taking part in an R-Ladies event you grant the community organizers full rights to use the images resulting from the photography/video filming/media, and any reproductions or adaptations of the images for publicity, fundraising or other purposes to help achieve the community’s aims. This might include (but is not limited to), the right to use them in their printed and online publicity, social media, press releases and funding applications. If you do not wish to be recorded in these media. please inform a community organizer.

title: R-Ladies Vienna
text:
As a local chapter of R-Ladies Global, we promote gender diversity in the R community in Vienna and worldwide. We aim to provide a safe and inclusive community space for R enthusiasts and practitioners of all experience levels with the R programming language, prioritizing anyone identifying as a minority gender to achieve proportionate gender representation. 🌈

title: Centralized database management with AWS and R/Shiny
text:
Abstract
Here is Ilaria’s and Mina’s abstract for the talk: As developers at a leading economic and financial markets research institution, centralizing our data is crucial for both internal (backtesting, sharing forecasts, model validations) and external (client access) use cases. Our contribution consists of two parts: first, the introduction of our R package, developed using the “Open API generator,” enabling seamless querying of our database via a RESTful API. Additionally, we show the integration of a robust authorization and authentication layer within AWS cloud infrastructure. Second, we have designed a user-friendly R/Shiny-based frontend to facilitate easy access for non-technical users. This interface displays forecasts and historic data for various variables and countries, allowing for data updates and downloads. To mimic familiar Excel operations such as row-wise pasting and data removal, we have successfully utilized the open-source R-wrapper rhandsontable of the JavaScript library handsontable. Both contributions enable our analysts and clients to smoothly interact with our database by providing a convenient, secure, and user-friendly environment, enhancing the accessibility of our macroeconomic data for all stakeholders.

title: Cluster analysis in R
text:
Date and Time
Thursday, 20 February 2025
6:00 PM - 7:30 PM CET


Venue
TU Wien, Freihaus - Seminarraum DA grün 04 (DA04E10)
Wiedner Hauptstraße 8-10 · Vienna


About
In our next meetup we will welcome Theresa Scharl-Hirsch for an introduction to cluster analysis and validation in R. Bring along your laptop to follow the presented examples and for some hands-on exercises!
Cluster analysis groups data based on similarities without relying on predefined labels, making it valuable in marketing, healthcare, social media and fraud detection. Unlike classification, which uses labelled data to assign data points to predefined categories, clustering works with unlabelled data to reveal hidden patterns.
Cluster validation ensures that the groups identified are meaningful using metrics such as compactness and separation, while visualisation tools such as scatter plots and dendrograms help to interpret the results. Common methods such as K-means, hierarchical clustering and model-based approaches are tailored to different data structures and objectives.


Speaker
Theresa Scharl-Hirsch
RSVP via Meetup

title: R You Ready? Integrating Large Language Models into your Workflow
text:
Date and Time
Monday, 28 April 2025
6:00 PM - 7:30 PM CEST


Venue
TU Wien, Freihaus - Seminarraum DA grün 06A (DA06E10)
Wiedner Hauptstraße 8-10 · Vienna


About
We warmly welcome R users of all identities and experience levels to our April meetup and learn about what you can achieve with large language models (LLMs) using R.
In this meetup, we will:

Walk through the essential background of modern LLMs, including their architecture and capabilities
Dive into the practical methods for harnessing the power of LLMs directly within R
Explore the growing ecosystem of R packages and APIs connecting to leading LLMs, demonstrating concrete use cases.

We look forward to seeing you at the meetup, where we foster a safe and inclusive space for knowledge exchange.Speaker


Speaker
Alexandra Posekany
Alex is an assistant professor and researcher in the field of computational statistics at TU Wien, who has developed state-of-the-art methods in the field throughout her career. She is also a vocational high school teacher in mathematics and data science. She has been a pioneer in integrating data science into the high school curriculum, promoting data literacy in education.

title: ggplot2 workshop with Ursula Laa
text:
Date and Time
Thursday, 27 May 2021
7:00 PM - 8:30 PM CEST


Venue
Online


About
We are happy to announce that for the May 2021 Meetup, our co-organizer Ursula Laa will offer a tutorial into data visualization with the R package ggplot2.
Starting from the underlying principles of tidy data and the grammar of graphics, Ursula will introduce the basic ingredients (aesthetics and geoms), and show how to build a ggplot layer-by-layer. We will see together how we can quickly generate very different graphs with small changes in a standard interface, making it easy to better explore data.


Speaker
Ursula Laa
Ursula is a researcher in the Statistics Institute of the University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences (BOKU) in Vienna and holds PhD in theoretical particle physics. She focuses her research on new methods and applications in data science with emphasis on interdisciplinary work, for example connecting her background in physics and her interest in statistical data visualization.

About
To complete topics that we did not manage to fit into the first workshop, we will host the second part of the Introduction to R Workshop in our next Meetup. This time we will cover:

Reading in data
Basic data visualization
R packages
R Markdown for writing reports

The workshop is open to everyone, in particular also if you did not make it to the first part! To catch up you can look at the first few sections of the workshop material prepared by Pia: Intro to R (up to the Data Structures section) or you could read through the Getting Started section of ModernDive.
As before, we recommend you bring your own laptop where you have R and RStudio installed. In case you want to install R Markdown, you can follow the instructions from R Markdown: The Definitive Guide.

title: Random projection for regression analysis in R
text:
Abstract
Random projection is a powerful and important tool for dimensionality reduction where a set of high-dimensional points is linearly mapped onto a lower dimension. Random projection matrices can be rapidly generated and are oblivious to the data distribution, maintain interpretability and are equipped with theoretical guarantees on preserving the geometry of the original space with a high probability. When employed in a supervised setting, they can provide a significant reduction in computational cost. However, they tend to overfit so it is desirable to first eliminate the unimportant predictors and then perform the random projection and estimate the model on the space of the reduced (i.e., projected) predictors. Moreover, to reduce the uncertainty from the random projection, ensembles can be built. In this work we propose an R package which implements a variety of random projection and screening tools for regression in high-dimensional settings. The functionality of the package is presented using simulated and real data examples.

title: Cross selling analytic model with sparklyr
text:
Date and Time
Thursday, 29 April 2021
6:00 PM - 8:00 PM CEST


Venue
Online


About
It is our pleasure to announce our speaker for April’s Meetup, Dr Carin Ludeña, who will be giving us insights into a sparklyr use-case for increasing bank revenue.
Looking forward to the interesting presentation and discussion and to seeing you soon (even though still in an online format)!


Speaker
Carin Ludeña
Carin is a mathematician, statistician, and data scientist who worked for many years as a university professor doing research on mathematical statistics, statistical learning, spatial statistics as well as graph and text analytics. Moreover, she acted as statistical advisor for an Election Monitoring ONG, a community (social and environmental) risk assessment project and lately in a large scale education monitoring process in Venezuela. As a data scientist, she advised and consulted in many projects ranging from statistical and mathematical models in oil production, to text analytics for automatic economic activity classification. Her current position, as data science leader in Matrix CPM, involves designing, developing and implementing solutions based on data and statistical/mathematical models, working hand in hand with data engineers.

title: Is ShinyApp in R production ready?
text:
Date and Time
Friday, 19 April 2024
4:00 PM - 7:00 PM CEST


Venue
TU Wien - Seminarraum 107/1 (im ehem. “Goldenen Lamm”)
Wiedner Hauptstraße 7, 1040 Vienna


About
In a previous meetup our own Mari Plaza has presented an introduction of Golem which allows you for sure to write a ShinyApp with the production ready mind-set. That means writing a ShinyApp like a package, including all relevant components of Software Engineering such modules, tests, dependencies, git, code coverage and so on. In such way, your Web Application developed in R is like a ShinyApp and has the correct architecture to go to production. This time, we go beyond an introduction session for a 3 hours workshop, starting with 1 hour of presentation about how you plan your application, followed by 2 hours of practical experience on how you use golem.
Bring your computer and be ready to ask questions and test by yourself what we are talking about.
Since the content is interesting and rather dense, you could join us in the preview activities starting at the end of February 2024, but you can always catch-up, even on the day of the event. The preview activities includes:

Join our SLACK dedicated channel for discussing the concepts and review related materials.
Follow posts in our LinkedIn accounts.
Regular updates through the messages of this event on MeetUp.

We are really happy to host this event with care and willingness to learn more about the great world of software engineering.


Speaker
María Inés Plaza Schwarck
María Inés Plaza is a production engineer and MBA which an interesting mix of skills and interests. Her passion for data, process improvement and constant curiosity led her to gain experience on Data Science and Strategy. Her unusual career path provide her with practical knowledge to be an integrator between Domain Knowledge, quantitative methods, technology and how do you communicate the insights.
RSVP via Meetup

title: Getting to know golem - R-Ladies Vienna December Meetup 2022
text:
Date and Time
Monday, 5 December 2022
12:00 PM - 1:00 PM CET


Venue
Hybrid:
TU Wien - Seminarraum 107/1 (im ehem. “Goldenen Lamm”)
Wiedner Hauptstraße 7, 1040 Vienna
or Online


About
Our last meetup of the year will take place in a HYBRID format, both live at TU Wien and online via zoom. Please note the family friendly time slot during the lunch break. You do not need to specify in advance whether you will participate online or live, but we would be happy to see you in person at TU Wien if you are available.
Our speaker is María Inés Plaza who will introduce us to golem, a package in R to develop production ready Shiny Apps. She will guide us through the content of the book Engineering Production Grade Shiny Apps and will share her experience developing apps with this package and methodology. This is a 100% interactive session where you could ask questions.
Since most probably many details will not be covered in the talk due to time constraints, you could join Mari at the Data Science Cafe on 9th December at WeXelerate to go into more details.
See you soon!
RSVP via Meetup
